abstract.para: Describes how a sipXecs system is installed, including initial configuration, and how service processes are managed.

revision.revremark: added detail with high level design information

section.title: Scenarios
section.para: This section is organized as a series of user workflow narratives: steps that a user (usually a &sipxecs; administrator) takes to accomplish some end.

section.title: Installation of a single system using ISO image
section.para: Our administrator chooses a system that meets the hardware requirements to be the new &sipxecs; server, inserts the &sipxecs; installation CD (or perhaps soon, a DVD) in the drive, and boots from it. After a prompt to ensure that it is acceptable to re-initialize the system and destroy all data on the drives, the installation run automatically, ejects the installation disk, and reboots.

Following the reboot, the user is prompted to log in as 'root' using the default 'setup' password, and a single-use script invokes the &sipxsetup; wizard. See for details of the &sipxsetup; application and what it configures.
The single-use script must de-activate itself so that it will not be run on subsequent root logins before it invokes the &sipxsetup; application, since that application may reboot the system.
After the &sipxsetup; application has established the minimal conditions for operation of &sipxsuper; and &sipxconfig;, it starts the &sipxsuper;.

section.title: Installation of a system using RPMs
section.para: Installation from RPMs can be done either by installing the individual rpms manually, or by configuring the package manager (yum, apt, or whatever) to include a repository containing them and directing the package manager to install the required components.

The &sipxecspgk; that installs all the &sipxecs; components. The recommended installation method is to install this umbrella rpm so that all components are installed. Installing a component does not configure any service to automatically start.

Following installation, the administrator must run the &sipxsetup; wizard program manually, which configures the minimum system parameters as it does when run in the iso installation (see ). If all of the minimal parameters are configured, the &sipxsetup; program configures the &sipxsuper; process to start automatically on the next reboot (and may also start it directly): see .

section.title: Initial Configuration with &sipxconfig;
section.para: The first time that the administrator logs in to the &sipxconfig; web user interface, a number of configuration choices must be made that establish the basic system parameters and configure each of the required services. Until the required services have been configured and activated, ordinary use of the &sipxconfig; administrative and user interfaces is not allowed; only a checklist of the remaining required choices is possible.

para.emphasis: The list above may be incomplete. In some cases, the user may be allowed to explicitly choose not to configure some of the system services.

section.title: Installation of a system cluster
section.para: The installation of a &sipxecs; cluster begins with the installation of the master system: from an iso image () or rpms (). Once the initial configuration with &sipxconfig; is complete, the user can choose to add a distributed system to the cluster (a single-system installation is just a degenerate case - a cluster with only one system).

section.title: Adding a distributed system
section.para:
The configuration operation in &sipxconfig; for adding a new system to the cluster requires:
The fully qualified domain name of the new system.
The IP address of the new system.
The set of services to be run on the new system. Some services (such as &sipxsuper; and ntpd) are required on every system in a cluster.
Additional information may be required depending on what services are selected.

The &sipxconfig; generates the initial configuration for the new system, including:
A TLS/SSL certificate
The configuration files for the services on the system.
When all required information has been provided and this configuration is ready, &sipxconfig; displays a system setup password value for the administrator. The administrator then install the distributed system.

section.title: Installation of a distributed system
section.para: Once the &sipxconfig; has prepared a configuration for the new distributed system, the administrator installs the &sipxecs; software on the new system either from an iso image or on an existing system from rpms. The administrator then executes the &sipxsetup; application (if using the iso installer, this happens on the first login as root). The &sipxsetup; application fetches the prepared configuration from the master system as described in .

section.title: Add a Service
section.para: To add a service to an existing installation, the administrator uses &sipxconfig; to first select the system in the cluster where the service should be added, and configures the service to run on that system. &sipxconfig; then collects any configuration information needed to initialize that service, and then activates the service.

section.title: Configuration Backup and Restore
section.para: It should be possible to back up only the master system to fully preserve all of the configuration for a cluster. Following a restore operation, &sipxconfig; must regenerate all service configurations for all services in the cluster.

section.title: Software Upgrade
section.para: The procedure to upgrade a &sipxecs; cluster is as follows:

step.para: The master system is upgraded first by installing the rpms and then restarting the &sipxecs; service.
When the &sipxsuper; starts, it compares its own version identifier to that of the current configuration on that system (see ).

If the previous version identifier is not the same as its own version (including if no previous version is recorded), &sipxsuper; does not start any configured services except &sipxconfig; on a master system.

When &sipxconfig; has confirmed that the stored configuration on a system in the cluster is appropriate for the version of software installed on that system, it invokes an XML RPC interface of &sipxsuper; to update the stored configuration version number on that system.

section.title: Components
section.para: This section is a functional description of the &sipxecs; components important to system and service configuration and managment.

section.title: &sipxsetup;
section.para: The &sipxsetup; is an application that gets the configuration data from the administrator that is essential to initializing the system and bringing up the &sipxsuper; process manager; it does this by performing the following steps:

step.para: Get a new password for the root account
The new root password is set immediately to maximize system security.
This step is skipped if the root password is not equal to the hardcoded &sipxecs; iso installation root password.
Initialize and start the network.

Collect the network parameters:
Host Name
IP Address
Netmask
Default Gateway IP Address
It then configures the network using the supplied parameters and attempts to start it. If the network startup succeeds, the &sipxsetup; proceeds; if not, it displays the standard error from the attempt to start and offers to repeat this step.
Set the system timezone.
This sets the timezone using the standard for the distribution; the default choice is whatever it is currently set to.
Set the system time.
This sets the time to a value in hours and minutes. The purpose is only to set an approximate time until ntp can be configured.
The default value is the time in the system clock.
Select system type from:

listitem.para: A new standalone or cluster master system; proceeds to
A distributed system to be added to an existing cluster; proceeds to

step.para: These steps are performed only when the system type selected is standalone or cluster master:

For a new (standalone or master) system installation, &sipxsetup; checks to see if a TLS/SSL certificate is installed, and if not prompts for the information needed to generate one:
SIP Domain Name
Organization Name
Section Name
Country Code
State or Province
Locality (city)
The SIP Domain Name is saved in the domain-config configuration file.
The TLS/SSL parameters are recorded, and then used to generate and install a self-signed CA certificate and a system certificate for the new system signed by that CA certificate.
Having set up the network and the TLS/SSL certificates, the minimal conditions are established to begin using &sipxconfig;, so &sipxsetup; completes as described in .
These steps are performed only when the system type selected is a distributed system:

When the admistrator chooses the "New distributed system" option, &sipxsetup; prompts for the name of the master system, and for the distributed system setup password supplied by &sipxconfig; when the distributed system was added.
The master system name is saved in the &sipxsuper; saved state for the system.

Using the provided master system name and password, &sipxsetup; contacts an 'Distributed System Setup Interface' provided by &sipxconfig; running on the master system (see . The new system authenticates itself to that service using the setup password (the connection to the master is encrypted with TLS/SSL, so the use of a plaintext password is safe). The initial setup service returns a prepared initial configuration for the system (see , which &sipxsetup; installs.

Having set up the network and the TLS/SSL certificate, the minimal conditions are established to begin using &sipxsuper; as the local agent for &sipxconfig;, so &sipxsetup; completes as described in .

When the minimal conditions are established for using &sipxconfig; and &sipxsuper;, the &sipxsetup; application configures the &sipxsuper; to start by default on reboot. &sipxsetup; then gives the user the choice of whether to:
exit to the shell
start the &sipxsuper; service and exit to the shell
reboot the system

section.title: &sipxsuper;
section.para: The &sipxsuper; is the master process management service for all &sipxecs; managed services on a system. The &sipxsetup; installation program establishes two items of configuration for &sipxsuper;:

listitem.para: The name of the master system for the cluster.
The TLS/SSL certificate that secures all communications with the the &sipxconfig; on the master system.

section.title: Service Definition
section.para: Each service installs a definition for itself in the /etc/sipxpbx/process.d directory; these definitions, and the commands from &sipxconfig; control the actions of &sipxsuper;.
The definition is an xml file using the sipXecs-process-01-00 schema. The service definition specifies the name and version of the service and has the following major sections:

section.title: Service Commands
section.para:
The command section specifies a command to execute for the following standard operations (some are optional):
Test the service configuration.
Start the service.
Stop the service.
Reload the service configuration.

section.title: Service Status
section.para:
The status section specifies the following ways for the &sipxsuper; to see the status of the process:
The path to the process id file.
A path to each log file.

section.title: Service Resources
section.para:
The resources section specifies each of the resources used by the process, and for each whether or not the resource must exist before the process can be started. The resources can be:
A path to a configuration file.
The name of another &sipxecs; service that must be running before this service is started.
The name of an in-memory database table that must be loaded before this service is started.
The name of a postgres database that must exist before this service is started.

The &sipxsuper; provides a set of XML RPC operations that allow &sipxconfig; to read, create, or modify the non-process resources required by any defined service; process resources can only be created by installing them and then &sipxconfig; can enable them.
Resource Security
The &sipxsuper; must not provide any operation that will create or modify anything on the system that is not declared as a resource by some service definition, and must not modify any part of any service definition. This is the basis of the system integrity protection.

section.title: Configuration Replication
section.para: All configuration for each &sipxecs; service is created by &sipxconfig; and replicated to the system where the service runs through &sipxsuper; (see ).

section.title: Service Control and Status
section.para: The &sipxsuper; maintains three peices of state with respect to each &sipxecs; service for which it has a definition:

listitem.para:
The desired state of the service on the system:
enabled
the service process should be active on this system
disabled
the service should not be active on this system

This value is set by &sipxconfig; (see ) when all configuration for the process has been replicated to the system. It records the version of the process for which the replicated configuration is intended. This value is used to check that the configuration version matches that of the service process before that process is started (see ).

The actual state of the process on the system:
ConfigurationVersionMismatch
the stored configuration version does not match the version in the process definition (see ).
ResourceRequired
some resource required by the process is not available
ConfigurationTestFailed
the service returned a failure status when its configuration test was exectuted.
Starting
the start command has been issued, the process is not yet known to be running (normally an ephemeral state).
StartingWarning
the start command has been issued, the process is not yet known to be running (normally an ephemeral state), but the configuration test returned a warning status before the process was started.
Running
the process is running.
RunningWarning
the process is running, but the configuration test returned a warning status before the process was started.
Restarting
the restart command has been issued, the process is not yet known to be running (normally an ephemeral state).
Stopping
the stop command has been issued, the process is still running (normally an ephemeral state).
NotRunning
the process is not running.

para.emphasis: Whether or not a service should be started is not a part of the process definition: it is separate state controlled by &sipxconfig;. The process definition is read-only data about the process installed with the the binaries and other static data it needs.

section.title: &sipxsuper; Startup

step.para: Before attempting to start any service, &sipxsuper; checks whether it is running on the master system:
If it is running on the master system, it proceeds with starting the services on the system (see subsequent steps).

If it is running on a distributed system, it first invokes a Distributed System Checkin method provided by &sipxconfig; on the master system (see ); the service does not provide any information to the distributed system, and cannot fail, so the &sipxsuper; proceeds as follows regardless of the result. The purpose of this checkin is to notify &sipxconfig; that the &sipxsuper; service on the distributed system is up so that it can check the distributed system configuration.
For each enabled service on the system, &sipxsuper;:

Compares the version of the process as specified by the process definition against the version written by &sipxconfig; when it configured the service (see ). If the versions match exactly, then &sipxsuper; proceeds to the next step; if not, the state of the service is set to ConfigurationVersionMismatch and no further attempt is made to start the process until this condition has been corrected by &sipxconfig;.
Checks that each required resource is satisfied.

If one is defined, it executes the configuration test command defined by the service. It reads any standard error output and saves it. The exit status of the test command is checked:
If the status is negative, the service cannot be started.
If the status is greater than zero, the service can be started but the process status is marked as having had a configuration warning.
If the status is zero, the test passes and the service can be started.
If all of the tests above pass, the start command for the service is executed.

section.para: A set of XML RPC operations is provided by &sipxsuper; to provide the current status of each enabled service (see .

section.title: Distributed System Setup Interface
section.para:
The Distributed System Setup Interface allows &sipxsetup; to fetch an initial system configuration. The interface is a simple HTTPS GET operation for a URL on the master system, authenticated using Basic authentication whose user name is "sipXsetup" and whose password is the value generated by &sipxconfig; for that distributed host.
The construction of the full URL for this request is TBD
The entity returned by this GET request is a gzipped tar file containing system configuration files to be installed as root from the root of the file system.
